Palladium immobilized on functionalized halloysite: A robust catalyst for ligand free Suzuki–Miyaura cross coupling and synthesis of pyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole motifs via four component cascade reaction and their in-silico antitubercular screening Pawan Kumar a Sakshi Panhotra a Muskan b Avtar Changotra b Sneh Lata c Ankit Mehta c Tamaghna Maitra d Princy Gupta a ⁎ a Department of Chemistry and Chemical Sciences, Central University of Jammu, Rahya-Suchani (Bagla), District-Samba, Jammu, J&K 181143, India Department of Chemistry and Chemical Sciences, Central University of Jammu, Rahya-Suchani (Bagla), District-Samba Jammu J&K 181143 India Department of Chemistry and Chemical Sciences, Central University of Jammu, Rahya-Suchani (Bagla), District-Samba, Jammu-181143, J&K, India. b Department of Chemistry, School of Sciences, Cluster University of Jammu, Canal Road, Jammu 180001, India Department of Chemistry, School of Sciences, Cluster University of Jammu Canal Road Jammu 180001 India Department of Chemistry, School of Sciences, Cluster University of Jammu, Canal Road, Jammu 180001, India. c Central Synthetic Chemistry Lab (CSCL), Department of Chemistry, SGT University, Gurgaon 122505, India Central Synthetic Chemistry Lab (CSCL), Department of Chemistry, SGT University Gurgaon 122505 India Central Synthetic Chemistry Lab (CSCL), Department of Chemistry, SGT University, Gurgaon-122505. d Beamline Development and Application Section, Bhabha Atomic Research Center, Trombay, Mumbai 400085, India Beamline Development and Application Section, Bhabha Atomic Research Center Trombay Mumbai 400085 India Beamline Development and Application Section, Bhabha Atomic Research Center, Trombay, Mumbai – 400085. ⁎ Corresponding author. This research introduces a novel organically functionalized halloysite-supported palladium catalyst, HMF-EDA-TMS@HAL-Pd(II) that was synthesized and thoroughly characterized using various analytical techniques like HR-TEM, FEG-SEM, EDX, XPS, FTIR, XRD, TGA, ICP-AES, EXAFS and DFT studies. The catalyst exhibited exceptional performance in Suzuki–Miyaura cross coupling reactions, demonstrating high efficiency and reusability up to seven cycles in aqueous ethanol medium. Motivated by its promising catalytic activity, we extended our investigation to explore its applicability in the synthesis of pyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole motifs via a four-component cascade reaction affording the desired products in good to excellent yields with broad substrate scope under green reaction conditions. In-silico antitubercular screening of pyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole motifs against DprE1 enzyme have shown promising results with inhibition constants ranging between 0.030 and 0.1 μM for compounds 5b, 5k and 5 l. This protocol has the advantages of wide substrate scope, high yield, excellent functional group tolerance, high efficiency and environmental benign procedure. These findings emphasized the catalyst's versatility and potential in diverse organic transformations, highlighting its importance in advancing sustainable synthetic methodologies. Graphical Abstract Keywords Halloysite nanotubes Suzuki–Miyaura cross coupling Pyrano[2 3-c]pyrazole motifs in-silico Antitubercular screening DprE1 enzyme Data Availability Data is included in the manuscript and in the supplementary information 1 Introduction Traditionally, Suzuki–Miyaura cross coupling have been catalyzed by Pd catalysts in homogeneous conditions involving the reaction between aryl halides and aryl boronic acids resulting in the construction of unsymmetrical biaryls with a high degree of selectivity and excellent tolerance towards a diverse range of functional groups [1–4]. Despite their effectiveness, the high cost of these catalysts and their limited efficiency in separation have hindered widespread industrial applications e.g. palladium-catalyzed reactions play a crucial role in the pharmaceutical industries for the synthesis of medicinal compounds where strict adherence to government regulations have specified residual metal content in the product typically set at less than 5 ppm [5]. To address these issues, substantial efforts have been dedicated to immobilize Pd complexes onto diverse separable supports, including carbon [6,7], silica [8], SBA-15 [9], polymers [10], organic-inorganic hybrids [11], CMC [12], MOF [13], COF [14], starch [15], clay [16] and carbon nanotubes [17] over the years. Unfortunately, supported Pd complex catalysts frequently encounter challenges such as decreased activity, compromised selectivity and issues like metal leaching and intricate preparation procedures. Extensive research demonstrates that Pd(II) acts as a Lewis acid interacting with various compounds to enable specific chemical transformations [18] particularly notable in reactions such as hydroethoxycarbonylation [19,20], synthesis of cyclic alkenyl ethers from acetylenic aldehydes [21] and asymmetric catalysis of carbon-carbon bond formation [22]. Pyrano[2,3-c]pyrazoles being an intriguing class of heterocyclic compounds draw significant attention in both organic chemistry and pharmaceutical research [23] due to their intricate molecular structures and diverse biological activities such as antimicrobial [24], anticancer [25], antiinflammatory [26] antiviral activities [27] and their ability to target the human Chk1 kinase enzyme ( Fig. 1) adds to their importance in molecular biology and therapeutic interventions [28]. Many synthetic methods have been developed for the synthesis of pyrano[2,3-c]pyrazoles such as four-component reaction of aldehydes/benzyl alcohols, ethyl acetoacetate, hydrazine hydrate/phenyl hydrazine hydrate and malononitrile [24,29]; three component reactions involving aromatic aldehyde, methyl-2-pyrazolin-5-one and malononitrile [30], and a copper catalyzed annulation of o-hydroxyphenyl propargylamines with pyrazolin-5-ones [31]. Another method of synthesis is the reaction of benzyl halide, malanonitrile/ethylcyanoacetate, or N-methyl-1-(methylthio)2-nitroethanamine [32], diethylacetylenedicarboxylate/ethyl acetoacetate and hydrazine hydrate [33] and five component reaction of acid chlorides, Meldrum’s acid, aromatic aldehydes, hydrazine hydrate and malononitrile. Various catalytic systems have been used for the synthesis of pyrano[2,3-c]pyrazoles such as Fe3O4–TiO [34], CuO-La2O3, [35] zinc triflate [36], Cu(OTf)2 [37], ionic liquids [38], organocatalyst [39], triethylamine [40], PPh3 [41], eosin Y [29], N-oxide-Ag2O [32], CeO2/ZrO2 [42], 18-C-6H3O+ [43], CMC-SO3H [44], TrCl [11], MIL-53(Fe) [45], AC-SO3H/[CholineCl][Urea]2 [46], β-cyclodextrin [47], γ-Fe2O3@cellulose-OSO3H [48] and Fe3O4@SiO2-EP-NH-HPA [49]. Tuberculosis was one of the most contagious diseases before COVID-19, impacting 10.6 million people worldwide and resulting in 1.6 million deaths annually [50]. Currently, decaprenylphosphoryl-β-D-ribose 2′-epimerase (DprE1) is a notable target for tuberculosis drug development because of its essential role in forming the mycobacterial cell wall, which contributes to the pathogen's resistance mechanisms [51]. To date, most DprE1-based inhibitors are undergoing clinical trials, indicating significant potential for discovering new drug candidates in this area [52,53]. Halloysite, a naturally occurring two-layered aluminosilicate (Al2Si2O5(OH)4×nH2O) similar to the kaolin clay group is an economically viable material that can be used for various applications. The various morphologies it exhibit arises from the proximity of alumina and silica layers, along with water of hydration, prompting curvature and rolling in multilayered tube formations thus, it is commonly known as halloysite nanotubes (HNTs)[54–57]. Its inner diameter is typically around 15 nm, outer diameter extends up to 50 nm and length up to approximately 800 ± 300 nm. The outer surface of HNTs is primarily composed of SiO₂, while the inner surface features a gibbsite-like array of Al–OH groups. This distinct chemical composition of its inner and outer surface allows for selective functionalization, enhancing its versatility in different applications. The outer surface carries a negative charge, while the inner lumen is positively charged. This property enhances the interaction of HNTs with various ionic and non-ionic compounds, making them suitable for applications from catalysis, drug delivery to environmental remediation [58–60]. In this work, we have synthesized halloysite-based palladium catalyst via surface modification with silane coupling agents followed by organic functionalization. Successful preparation of the catalyst was confirmed by different characterization techniques and was found highly efficient for ligand free Suzuki–Miyaura cross coupling in an air atmosphere. The Lewis acidity of prepared palladium catalyst has also been explored for four-component synthesis of pyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole derivatives and all derivatives were screened for their in-silico antitubercular study. Green reaction conditions, ease of catalyst separation, simple purification procedure and reusability of catalyst up to seven cycles are the main advantages of the present protocol. 2 Experimental 2.1 Material and instruments All the chemicals for catalyst preparation and reaction were purchased from Aldrich or Merck companies and used as such without any purifications. SEM images were recorded using JEOL Model JSM-7600F scanning electron microscope, EDX analysis was carried out using JEOL Model JSM-7600F and high-resolution transmission electron micrographs (HR-TEM) were recorded on FEI Model Tecnai G2, F30. Brucker Model 3000 Hyperion microscope with vertex 80 FTIR spectrophotometer was used to record the FTIR spectra of the samples. Inductively coupled plasma–atomic emission spectrometry (ICP-AES) SPECTRO analytical instruments GmbH, Germany, Model ARCOS, simultaneous ICP spectrometer was used for estimation of palladium in catalyst. X-ray Photo-electron spectroscopy (XPS) analysis was carried out using a Thermoscientific NEXA surface analyzer model for the determination of oxidation states. X-ray diffractograms (XRD) were recorded in a 2theta range of 5–100 on a Bruker D8-Advance X-ray diffractometer using Cu Ka radiation. TGA was recorded on a Perkin Elmer, Diamond TG/DTA. The 1H and 13C NMR data were recorded in CDCl3 and DMSO-d6 on a JEOL JNM/ECZ 500/S1 series (500 MHz). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Characterization of catalyst In this protocol, we have synthesized supported palladium catalyst on organically functionalized halloysite (HMF-EDA-TMS@HAL-Pd(II)) and its successful preparation was confirmed by performing different structural characterization techniques such as FTIR, XRD, HR-TEM, FEG-SEM, EDX, SAED, XPS, TGA and EXAFS. The structure of the catalyst was further confirmed by DFT studies which was in synergism with the experimental results. To study the structure and confirm the successful modification of each step pristine halloysite (HAL), HAL@TMS, EDA-HAL@TMS, HMF-EDA-HAL@TMS, HMF-EDA-TMS@HAL-Pd(II) were subjected to FTIR spectroscopy as depicted in Fig. 2. FTIR spectra of pristine HAL are in good accordance with previous reports and exhibited the characteristic bands at 529 cm−1 and 461 cm−1 for Al-O-Si and Si-O-Si vibrations respectively; Si-O band at 908 cm−1 and inner surface Al-OH stretching vibration at 3698 cm−1 and 3624 cm−1 [61]. All these vibrational bands are also found in the spectra of each step of modification. New absorption bands at 2943 cm−1 and 764 cm−1 of CH2 and C-Cl stretching absorptions were observed which confirmed the modification of halloysite with TMS. Coupling of TMS with EDA was established by the presence of new absorption stretching and bending vibrational bands at 3200–3391 cm−1 and 1557 cm−1 respectively, for surface NH2 functional group. A new C-N stretching band was band observed at 1283 cm−1 while C-Cl stretching band at 764 cm−1 disappeared. Finally, a new band at 1669 cm−1 and 1196 cm−1 appeared were characteristic band of C=N and C-O functionality indicated the reaction of EDA and HMF. The existence of all the stretching and bending vibrations confirmed the successful modifications at each successive step. Moreover, all the surface functionalities were confirmed by the presence of their corresponding bands in the FTIR of catalyst as fresh and after used in Suzuki–Miyaura cross coupling reaction. X-ray diffraction (XRD) analysis was employed to elucidate the structural features of the catalyst and to confirm whether the structure of HAL remain unaltered during the surface decoration with organic modification and the incorporation of Pd species. The XRD patterns of the as-synthesized HMF-EDA-TMS@HAL-Pd(II) catalyst ( Fig. 3) showed a peak at 12.19° (d001 = 7.25 Å) has been identified as originating from halloysite (7 Å), determined through the intensity ratio between (002) reflections at 24.79° (d002 = 3.32 Å) and (020/110) reflections at 20.13° (d020/110 = 4.40 Å), which is less than 2. Peaks with d values of 3.32 Å and 2.98 Å, respectively were indicative of quartz (SiO2) and alumite (KAl3(SO4)2(OH)6) patterns of halloysite [62]. The additional peaks at (2θ) of 39, 45.78 and 68.11 were assigned to the planes (111), (200) and (220), respectively for face-centered cubic (fcc) crystalline structure of Pd (JCPDS Card No. 46–1043) [63]. The detailed examination of the catalyst's morphology was successfully carried out through the use of high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) and scanning electron microscopy (SEM) images. The synthesized sample demonstrates a well-defined tubular structure, as seen in high-resolution transmission electron microscopy (HR-TEM) micrographs ( Fig. 4a, b). Notably, the HR-TEM images illustrate an effective distribution of palladium nanoparticles on HAL surface indicating successful synthesis with uniform dispersion. The confirmation of presence of palladium nanoparticles is validated by analyzing the interplanar spacing (Fig. 4c), which is 0.225 nm for the Pd (111) plane [64], also supported by the XRD pattern. This precise interplanar spacing aligns with the expected structure of palladium, providing conclusive evidence of the existence of Pd species in the prepared catalyst. The tubular shape, coupled with the well-distributed palladium nanoparticles enhance the overall surface area and accessibility of active sites, contributing to the catalytic efficiency and performance of the material. The persistent tubular structure underlines the robustness of the synthetic process, ensuring its stability for up to seven consecutive cycles for Suzuki–Miyaura cross coupling (Fig. 4e, f). Field emission gun-scanning electron microscopy (FEG-SEM) images ( Fig. 5) revealed a distinctive tubular and uniform morphology providing crucial insights into the catalyst's structural characteristics. Additionally, the elemental composition of the catalyst was confirmed using energy dispersive X-ray (EDX) spectroscopy showing the presence of carbon (C), oxygen (O), aluminum (Al), silicon (Si) and palladium (Pd). The EDX elemental mapping further demonstrated a homogeneous distribution of these elements across the catalyst's surface ( Fig. 6). This comprehensive analysis not only emphasized the specific morphological attributes of the catalyst but also elucidates elemental composition and distribution contributing valuable information for a more understanding of its catalytic applications. The EDX data of catalyst’s precursors i.e. HAL@TMS, EDA-HAL@TMS, HMF-EDA-HAL@TMS are given in supplementary information. X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) was employed to examine the chemical oxidation state of the supported palladium species in the HMF-EDA-TMS@HAL-Pd(II) catalyst. In Fig. 7 the XPS spectrum displayed doublet peaks at a binding energy of 336.6 eV and 342.2 eV corresponding to the electron transitions of Pd (II) in the 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 states respectively [65]. This observation confirmed the initial presence of divalent palladium in the fresh catalyst. Whereas, the binding energies at 334.9 eV and 340.7 eV corresponded to the characteristic absorption peaks of Pd (0) for the 3d5/2 and 3d3/2 states respectively [66]. This suggested that Pd (II) undergoes reduction to metallic Pd (0) during the reaction process which is consistent with existing literature supporting the understanding that the palladium species undergo a chemical transformation from a divalent state Pd (II) to a metallic state Pd(0) during Suzuki–Miyaura cross coupling reaction. The thermal stability of the catalyst was assessed through thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) ( Fig. 8). The initial weight loss of approximately 1.2 % observed up to 200 °C was ascribed to the desorption of intercalated water molecules. Subsequently, a substantial weight loss of 32.51 % occurred up to 556 °C which was attributed to the decomposition of organic functionalities present on the surface of HAL. These results establish the catalyst's high thermal stability, thereby affirming its suitability for conducting reactions safely up to 200 °C. Extended X-ray absorption fine structure (EXAFS) spectra at the Pd K-edge for Pd foil, Pd(OAc)₂, fresh and used catalyst (PO1 and PO2) are shown in Fig. 9a. Corresponding Fourier transformed R-space plots are displayed in Fig. 9b. The R-space plots derived from EXAFS data clearly display the Pd-Pd and Pd-O peaks in the foil and acetate standard. In the Pd K-edge spectra of the catalysts, however, there is considerable disorder in the Pd-Pd scattering amplitude when compared to that of the Pd foil. This result is further visualized through the wavelet transform. A weak contribution is evident at the R-value (∼1.3 Å) where Pd-N/Pd-O bond is expected in both fresh (PO1) and used (PO2) catalyst. 3.2 Computational details All the theoretical calculations were performed using Gaussian09 (Revision D.01) suite of quantum chemical programs [67]. Ground-state geometry optimization of the catalyst was carried out using the B3LYP-D3 hybrid density functional [68]. The 6–31 G** basis set [69] for atoms (C, H, N, O, Si) and Stuttgart−Dresden double-ζ basis set (SDD) with effective core potential was used for palladium atom (28,18) with 28 core and 18 valence electrons [70]. The effect of solvent was incorporated using SMD continuum solvation model (water, ε=78.35) popularized by Cramer and Truhlar [71]. Vibrational frequencies were calculated on the optimized structure to ensure that the optimized geometry represent the local minima and there are only positive eigenvalues. Graphical representation of the optimized structure was obtained by CYLview software [72]. Different possibilities have been considered for the formation of an active catalyst as shown in Fig. 10. The acetate can act as both monodendate or bidendate ligand since it has two donor sites [73]. Among the different possibilities considered, the species E was found to be the lowest in terms of relative Gibbs free energy, where one of acetate ligand acts in bidendate fashion coordinating to both the palladium centers and other acetate ligand coordinates to both the metal centers through the same oxygen donor site. In the lowest energy active species E, Pd---Pd interaction was observed and each palladium metal center tends to stay in square planar geometry. Each palladium metal center is coordinated by monodendate acetate ligand which occupies the third coordination site around palladium metal center. The fourth coordination site is occupied by oxygen atom of furfuryl alcohol around one palladium metal center, whereas, around other palladium metal center it is occupied by nitrogen atom of ethylenediamine moiety. The distances mentioned in Fig. 10 E are in angstroms. The computational data is given in supplementary information. 3.3 Catalytic performance for Suzuki–Miyaura cross coupling The catalytic efficacy of the prepared catalyst was evaluated for Suzuki–Miyaura cross coupling reactions taking p-iodoanisole and phenylboronic acid as model substrates and systematically explored different solvents and bases to optimize the Suzuki–Miyaura cross coupling in presence of prepared HMF-EDA-TMS@HAL-Pd(II) catalyst. Initial attempts to optimize the reaction conditions were conducted in environmental-friendly aqueous conditions at room temperature using 0.06 mol% of catalyst in the presence of K2CO3 base. In solvent screening, aqueous ethanol emerged as the most effective solvent. When EtOH was replaced with other conventional alcohols like n-propanol and i-propanol ( Table 1 , entries 4, 5) and solvent was switched to acetonitrile (Table 1 entry 6), poor yields were obtained. Temperature is another important parameter as subsequent experimentation demonstrated that elevating the temperature to 60 °C led to a notable enhancement in both the reaction rate and yield (Table 1 , entries 4 and 7). Further increasing temperature to reflux resulted in a 94 % yield within a remarkably short duration of 20 min. (Table 1 , entry 9). Further investigations into different bases like K2CO3, KOH, NaOH and Cs2CO3 in aqueous ethanol revealed that only Cs2CO3 demonstrated effectiveness in facilitating the Suzuki–Miyaura cross and other bases resulted in less effective coupling. The optimization of catalyst loading was also investigated under reflux in aqueous ethanol. When 0.03 mol% of catalyst was employed, the reaction required a longer time to go to completion. Conversely, increasing the catalyst loading from 0.06 mol% to 0.09 mol% resulted in an improved reaction rate, yet no discernible enhancement in yield was observed. Notably, when the reaction was conducted without catalyst (Table 1 , entry 14), no reaction was evident even after 16 h, highlighting the effectiveness of the prepared catalyst. So, entry 9 (Table 1) was selected as the optimized reaction condition for this reaction. Under optimized reaction conditions, this catalytic process demonstrated excellent tolerance towards a variety of functional groups ( Scheme 1) both activated aryl halides such as 3-cynoiodobenzene, 4-cynoiodobenzene, 2-iodoacetophenone and deactivated aryl iodides such as 4-methyliodobenzene, 3-methoxyiodobenzene, 4-methoxyiodobenzene affording the corresponding coupling products in excellent yields. Also, the catalytic system exhibited a wide range of substrate compatibility with both simple and heterocyclic aryl halides/boronic acids that coupled rapidly to produce corresponding biaryl products. Ortho-substituent aryl iodide derivatives whether activating (2-iodoacetophenone) or deactivating (2-iodoaniline) although offer good yields, reactions were sluggish may be due to some steric factors. Heterocyclic boronic acid derivatives such as thiophene-3-boronic acid and 2-methoxypyridine-5-boronic acid also offered excellent results under optimized reaction conditions. All the desired products were obtained simply by recrystallization from ethanol, thus obviating the need for any chromatographic purifications. To demonstrate the efficacy of the newly devised protocol for Suzuki–Miyaura cross coupling, a comparison of the catalytic activity between of HMF-EDA-TMS@HAL-Pd(II) and several reported catalytic systems was carried out. The results are presented in Table 2, remarkably, under optimized reaction conditions HMF-EDA-TMS@HAL-Pd(II) demonstrates markedly superior performance compared to most of the reported protocols. 3.3.1 Recyclability of HMF-EDA-TMS@HAL-Pd(II) catalyst for Suzuki–Miyaura coupling Recycling the catalyst is a critical consideration in heterogeneous reactions. As highlighted previously, the easy recovery through filtration or centrifugation is a major benefit of utilizing an immobilized catalyst. The study also explored the potential for recycling HMF-EDA-TMS@HAL-Pd(II) catalyst through the coupling of 4-iodoanisole with phenylboronic acid in aqueous ethanol under optimized reaction conditions. As depicted in Fig. 11, the catalyst demonstrated the capability to be recovered and reused for seven cycles without experiencing a notable decline in catalytic activity. Comparison of HR-TEM of catalyst before and after seven runs (Fig. 4) showed that Pd nanoparticles dispersed over the surface of HAL after seven runs, indicating the evolution of Pd nanoparticles during catalytic reactions. ICP-AES analysis demonstrated that loss of active Pd species was negligible. This high stability and excellent reusability of the catalyst were attributed to strong coordination bonds. Upon completion of the reaction, the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture via membrane filtration assembly using 0.022 UM filter paper, followed by washing with hot H2O and MeOH (3×25 mL each), dried in an oven at 80 °C overnight and used for subsequent runs. 3.3.2 Catalytic performance for tandem synthesis of pyrano[2,3-c]pyrazoles A systematic investigation into the optimization of reaction parameters for the synthesis of pyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole derivatives was carried out using equimolar quantities of 4-bromobenzaldehyde, ethyl acetoacetate, hydrazine hydrate and malononitrile. The optimization involves variety of conventional organic solvents, including ethanol, water, ethanol-water mixtures and n-propanol ( Table 3 , entries 5–8) each with varying characteristics that influence the reaction outcome. Solvent selection plays a critical role in dictating reaction outcomes among tested solvents, ethanol and ethanol-water mixtures demonstrated superior performance may be due to their ability to solvate reactants effectively and stabilize reaction intermediates. Initially, the reaction in ethanol solvent produced low yield of the desired product at room temperature in 12 h. Temperature variation revealed its significance in driving reaction kinetics, ason rising temperature from room temperature to reflux accelerated the formation of the desired product 78 % in 1.25 h (Table 3 , entries 1–3). Then the influence of catalyst concentration, from 0.03 mol%, 0.045 mol%, to 0.06 mol%, enhanced desired product formation (Table 3 , entries 3–5). Upon further increasing the catalyst loading to 0.09 mol%, surprisingly no improvement in yield was found (Table 3 , entry 9). Thus, ethanol-water (1:1) at reflux using 0.06 mol% afforded the maximum yield of 92 % desired product in 20 min. was considered as the best conditions for this four-component synthesis of pyrano[2,3-c]pyrazoles. Moreover, in the absence of catalyst, only 64 % yield was obtained in 6 h which shows that the presence of a catalyst is necessary for achieving complete conversion as well as improving the selectivity of this transformation. Under optimized conditions, the reaction was carried out with a variety of substituted aryl aldehydes and found to have a wide substrate scope for this reaction ( Scheme 2). Aromatic aldehydes, whether bearing electron-donating groups (e.g., Me, OMe) or electron-withdrawing groups (e.g. F, Br, Cl, NO2) at the para position and also, substituents at meta position e.g. 3-Br-4-F and 3-NO2 furnished good to excellent results. However, heterocyclic aldehydes e.g. 3-methyl-2-thiophene carboxaldehyde and quionoline-4-carbozxaldehyde afforded moderate yields. Pure products were acquired through straightforward recrystallization from ethanol obviating the requirement for any chromatographic techniques. 3.3.3 In-silico antitubercular study of pyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole motifs The molecules discussed in this work are known for their anticancer properties. In the current study, we repurposed these molecules to evaluate their antituberculosis activity against DprE1 using molecular docking. The 3D crystal structure of the DprE1 protein from tuberculosis (PDB ID: 4P8C, X-ray diffraction, resolution 1.95 Å), complexed with the non-covalent inhibitor QN127, was retrieved from the RCSB Protein Data Bank (http://www.rcsb.org) [84]. This enzyme consists of two protein chains (A and B), comprising 448 and 417 amino acids, respectively. The active binding site of the QN127 inhibitor in the 4P8C receptor was used to establish the docking grid for our compounds, and the XYZ coordinates of the binding site were recorded as configurations 2 and 4 for our docking studies in chains B and A, respectively. 3.3.3.1 Receptor preparation The downloaded 3D crystal structure of DprE1 enzymes was imported into PyMOL, where all co-crystallized heteroatoms, water molecules, and ligands were removed. The processed crystal structure was saved in PDB format and imported into AutoDock Vina [85,86]. The receptor protein was further refined by adding polar hydrogens and Kollman charges. AutoDock Vina can also remove water molecules if not done in PyMOL. The processed receptor protein was saved as a PDBQT file, and the grid was generated using the bound ligand QN127 as a reference for both chains (A and B). The grid parameters in XYZ coordinates were specified as configurations 4 and 2. 3.3.3.2 Preparation of ligand All pyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole derivatives (5a-5l) were optimized to stable 3D structural geometries using Gaussian 09 W with DFT calculations and a 6–31 G basis set. These optimized derivatives were saved as MDL files. The MDL files of optimized Pyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole derivatives (5a-5l) were converted to PDB format using PyMOL, and the PDB files of the optimized ligands were saved as PDBQT input files using the AutoDock Vina package. This process further stabilized the ligands by merging non-polar hydrogens, assigning Gasteiger charges, detecting aromatic carbons, and adjusting rotatable bonds and torsional degrees of freedom (TORSDOF). 3.3.4 Docking protocol The docking region of the receptor was defined as C2 and C4 grid boxes, each measuring 40x40x40 Å with a spacing of 0.375 Å. These boxes were positioned around the binding site of Q127, as calculated from the original crystal structure. The coordinates for the docking grid boxes in configurations C2 and C4 were 56.669, −25.207, 28.421, and 15.981, −19.936, 7.199, respectively. CMD commands were employed to calculate the docking scores [85,86] of various ligands against the DprE1 receptor (4P8C) within the specified grid boxes of configurations C2 and C4 for chains A and B. The docking scores, expressed as ΔG values in kcal/mol, ranged from −7.125 kcal/mol to −10.25 kcal/mol and are presented in Table 4. The inhibition constant for each docking score was calculated using the formula Ki = e^(ΔG/RT), as shown in Table 4. The docked ligands 5k and 5l within the receptor’s chain A are illustrated in Fig. 12a is the binding of compound 5k and Fig. 12b is the binding of compound 5l in receptor’s chain A Compound 5k ( Fig. 13), with a binding energy of −10.08 kcal/mol, forms two hydrogen bond interactions: one between the amino group of the pyran ring and ARG-242 and another between the oxygen of the pyran ring and GLU-294. Additionally, four hydrophobic interactions occur: between ARG-242 and the methyl carbon at position 5; GLU-294 and the meta position of the N-phenyl ring; ALA-207 and the meta position of the N-phenyl ring; and TYR-297 and the ortho position to the bromophenyl substituent at position 4. One π-π interaction between the pyrazole ring and ARG-242A also contributes to the binding of compound 5k with the 4P8C chain A. Compound 5l (Fig. 13), with an inhibition constant value of 47 nM, exhibits a π-π interaction between the pyrazole ring and ARG-242A. This interaction is further supported by five hydrophobic interactions: between the ortho position of bromofluorophenyl and TYR-297A; the methyl group at position 5 and ARG-242A; the meta position of the N-phenyl ring and GLU-204A, ARG-298A, and ALA-207A. All these interactions occur within a distance of 4 Å around compound 5l. The interaction of compound 5b with the receptor 4P8C is shown in Fig. 14 . The spectral data of representative compounds of Suzuki–Miyaura cross coupling and pyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole series are given in the supplementary information. 4 Conclusion In conclusion, the present study demonstrated the synthesis and characterization of the novel organically functionalized halloysite-supported palladium catalyst methodically characterized through a range of analytical techniques and its exceptional performance in Suzuki–Miyaura cross coupling reactions and notable reusability up to seven cycles. Encouraged by these results, our investigation was extended to evaluate its catalytic efficiency for the synthesis of pyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole motifs through a four-component cascade reaction. Remarkably, the catalyst exhibited high efficiency in this multicomponent synthesis, giving the desired products in high yields with wide substrate scope. The successful application of this catalyst in both Suzuki–Miyaura cross coupling reactions and the synthesis of pyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole motifs highlights its promising role in catalysis and motivates further exploration of its capabilities in various organic transformations. For in-silico antitubercular screenings, three compounds 5b, 5k, and 5 l exhibited good binding energy with 4P8C. Of these, 5k is the most significant compound, displaying promising binding with chains A and B at concentrations of 0.04 and 0.1 μM. 4.1 Synthesis of HMF-EDA-TMS@HAL-Pd(II) Catalyst The systematic route of preparation of functionalized halloysite immobilized palladium (II) catalyst HMF-EDA-TMS@HAL-Pd(II) is displayed in Scheme 3 was achieved in the following four steps: 4.2 Synthesis of TMS@HAL In a typical procedure, 1 g of pristine halloysite (HAL) was dispersed in 30 mL of toluene at room temperature for 15 min. and then 2 gm (10 mmol) of 3-chloropropyl (trimethoxy)silane was added to it and the reaction mixture was refluxed for 24 h. The residue was filtered off at vacuum pump, washed with toluene (3×25 mL) and dried at 80 °C in an oven for overnight to get TMS@HAL. 4.3 Synthesis of EDA-TMS@HAL The prepared TMS@HAL was dispersed in 30 mL toluene for 15 min. and then ethylenediamine (EDA) 0.78 g (13 mmol) was added and the reaction mixture was reflux for 24 h and the residue was filtered off at vacuum pump, washed with toluene (3×25 mL) and dried at 60 °C in an oven for overnight to get EDA-TMS@HAL. 4.4 Synthesis of HMF-EDA-TMS@HAL EDA-TMS@HAL was dispersed in 30 mL toluene for 15 min. and then 5-hydroxymethyl furfural (HMF) 1.63 g (13 m mol) was added and reaction mixture was refluxed for 24 h, the residue was filtered off under vacuum, washed with toluene (3×25 mL) and dried at 60 °C in an oven for overnight to get HMF-EDA-TMS@HAL. 4.5 Synthesis of HMF-EDA-TMS@HAL-Pd(II) Finally, prepared support HMF-EDA-TMS@HAL was dispersed in 30 mL toluene for 15 min. and then a methanolic solution of Pd(OAc)2 (0.03 g in 10 mL of MeOH) was added and the reaction was allowed to run at room temperature for 10 h. The achieved product was vacuum filtered and washed with toluene, methanol and distilled water (3×25 mL each) to remove physically adsorbed palladium acetate, if any. The obtained HMF-EDA-TMS@HAL-Pd(II) was then dried at 80 °C in an oven for 24 h. 4.6 General procedure for Suzuki–Miyaura cross coupling Aryl halides (1 mmol), arylboronic acid (1.2 mmol) subjected to cross-coupling in the presence of K2CO3 base (2 mmol) and HMF-EDA-TMS@HAL-Pd(II) catalyst (50 mg, 0.06 mol%), in EtOH/H2O (1:1 mL) under reflux conditions in an air atmosphere for appropriate time as monitored by thin-layer chromatography (TLC). Upon completion of the reaction, the catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture via filtration, followed by washing with H2O and MeOH (3×25 mL each), and used for subsequent runs. The crude product was extracted with ethyl acetate and the organic phase was separated and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4 and solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure. Finally, desired products were purified by recrystallization from EtOH (compounds 3c, 3 h, 3i and 3 l were purified by column chromatography 90:6–80:20 % (petroleum ether:ethyl acetate). 4.7 General procedure for the synthesis of pyrano[2,3-c]pyrazoles A mixture of ethyl acetoacetate (1 mmol) and hydrazine hydrate or phenyl hydrazine hydrochloride (1 mmol) was stirred at room temperature for 2 min. in presence of HMF-EDA-TMS@HAL-Pd(II) catalyst then aldehydes (1 mmol) and malononitrile (1 mmol) were added; then the reaction mixture was refluxed in EtOH/H2O (1:1 mL) for an appropriate time and progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC. After completion of reaction catalyst was separated from the reaction mixture by filtration, washed with H2O and MeOH (3×25 mL each) and used for subsequent runs. Then, the crude product was extracted with ethyl acetate and organic phase was separated and dried over anhydrous Na2SO4 and then solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure. Finally, desired products were purified by recrystallization from EtOH. Declaration of Competing Interest The authors declare no competing interests. coredata.dc:description: This research introduces a novel organically functionalized halloysite-supported palladium catalyst, HMF-EDA-TMS@HAL-Pd(II) that was synthesized and thoroughly characterized using various analytical techniques like HR-TEM, FEG-SEM, EDX, XPS, FTIR, XRD, TGA, ICP-AES, EXAFS and DFT studies. The catalyst exhibited exceptional performance in Suzuki–Miyaura cross coupling reactions, demonstrating high efficiency and reusability up to seven cycles in aqueous ethanol medium. Motivated by its promising catalytic activity, we extended our investigation to explore its applicability in the synthesis of pyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole motifs via a four-component cascade reaction affording the desired products in good to excellent yields with broad substrate scope under green reaction conditions. In-silico antitubercular screening of pyrano[2,3-c]pyrazole motifs against DprE1 enzyme have shown promising results with inhibition constants ranging between 0.030 and 0.1 μM for compounds 5b, 5k and 5 l. This protocol has the advantages of wide substrate scope, high yield, excellent functional group tolerance, high efficiency and environmental benign procedure. These findings emphasized the catalyst's versatility and potential in diverse organic transformations, highlighting its importance in advancing sustainable synthetic methodologies.
